translated: If, on the other hand, the imperishable were assumed to be something different from the highest Lord, possessing the attributes of being invisible, &c, it would not be the highest knowledge, and the distinction of the two kinds of knowledge would be lost, since that distinction is based on the fact that the one knowledge has for its result the highest human end, the other the mere attainment of heaven and so on But the knowledge of the pradhÄna is not admitted by any one to have for its result the highest human end And a third kind of knowledge would have to be assumed, since according to your doctrine the highest Self is taught as something different from the imperishable source of the elements But only two kinds of knowledge are mentioned in the passage, That which thou seest as common to all, know that to be the lower; but that which thou seest as different, know that to be the higher GÄ« , , And the passage, When the one is known, everything else is known Mu Up , , , , intimates that the knowledge of everything else depends on the knowledge of the one, a fact which is possible only if Brahman is meant, which is the Self of everything, not if the pradhÄna is meant, which is the abode of mere nonintelligent matter, or if the enjoyer is meant, who is different from the objects of enjoyment Moreover, the passage, He taught the highest knowledge, the foundation of all knowledge, to Atharvan, his eldest son Mu Up , , , intimates that the knowledge of the pradhÄna is not the highest knowledge, since it is said to be taught by Brahman to his son
